title: The Works of Robert Louis Stevenson - Swanston Edition, Vol. 16
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: On Tweedside, or by Lyne or Manor,we have spent together whole afternoons; to me, at the time, extremelywearisome; to him, as I am now sorry to think, bitterly mortifying.

title: The Works of Robert Louis Stevenson - Swanston Edition, Vol. 16
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: There is a parish of Stevenston in Cunningham; a secondplace of the name in the Barony of Bothwell in Lanark; a third on Lyne,above Drochil Castle; the fourth on the Tyne, near Traprain Law.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Tam Todd has long since gone theway of all the earth, and lies in Lyne Kirkyard with a flat stone abovehim.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: It was on a very fresh, sweet May morning, that Marjory and Iwere married in the old Kirk of Lyne, which stands high on a knoll abovethe Lyne Water, with green hills huddled around the door.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: I crossed Lyne abune theBrig, and came doun Stobo burn, and here I am.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Now this same Tarth a little way down flows into theLyne, which enters Tweed almost opposite the house of Barns.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: I thought of goldenafternoons in the woods of Dawyck, or the holms of Lyne, of how theyellow light used to make the pools glow, and the humming of bees wasmingled with the cry of snipe and the song of linnet.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: I sawthe thin smoke curling up from the little village of Lyne, and Lyne Kirkstanding on its whin-covered brae, and the bonny holms of Lyne Water,where I had often taken great baskets of trout.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: We did not bury him in the Kirk of Lyne, for he had alwayssaid he never could abide to lie within walls.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: I feared to come to Dawyck too early, so I forded Tweed belowthe island, and took the road up the further bank by Lyne and Stobo.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: He died suddenly, of overdrinking, at the age offifty-five, and now lies in the kirk of Lyne beneath an effigyrepresenting the Angel Gabriel coming for his soul.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: He preached every Sabbath inthe little kirk of Lyne, below the Roman camp, and a woful service itwas.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: I had escaped the watchful care of my tutor, MasterRobert Porter, the curate of Lyne, who vexed my soul thrice a week withCaesar and Cicero.

title: Rab and His Friends and Other Papers
author: Brown, John
snippet: From thence he went to Lyne's Mill, near his birthplace, where he continued one year at the same employment, and from thence he was sent to Edinburgh to learn brush-making, but made no progress in his education there; was annoyed by the wicked boys, or _keelies_, as he called them, and found his way back to Manor and Woodhouse.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: The county is well watered bythe Tweed, Lyne, Leilhen, Eddleston, Manor, and several other inferior streams.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: M'edwin, a small river of Scotland, inLanarkshire, one-half of which falls intothe Tarth, and this latter into the Lyne,which joins the Tweed, while the otherhalf runs into the Clyde.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: Lyne, a river of England, in Northumberland, which falls into the sea, near Cars-well.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: Lyne, a river of England, in Staffordshire, which falls into the Trent.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: Lyne, a river of Scotland, in Peeblesshire, which has its rise on the borders ofthe county of Edinburgh, and falls into theTweed about three mires above Peebles.

title: Weir of Hermiston :
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: sat, when his master condescended to return, and drive off at last down-hill, along the curve of Lyne- doch Place; but even so sitting, as he passed the end of his father's street, he took one glance from between shielding ringers, and beheld a doctor's carriage at the door.

title: Redgauntlet :
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The voices, as they mixed in their several parts, and ran through them, untwisting and again entwining all the links of the merry old catch, seemed to have a little touch of the bacchanalian spirit which they celebrated, and shewed plainly that the musicians were engaged in the same joyous  revel as the menyie of old Sir Thorn a Lyne.

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: The Rev.Alexander Johnston of Lyne and Meggat, the latteradjoining Yarrow, continued to preach in his 102ndyear.3 His utterance, however, was somewhat indistinct.

title: Recollections of a Visit to Glasgow with the British Archæological Associations, August 27th to September 5th, 1888. With notes
author: Lambert, George
snippet: Very little now remainedof the palace but the west wall, built upon a steep slope,at the bottom of which was the water of Lyne or " TowerBurn."
